122.storedString:
DBJr is an end-user authoring system in the tradition of HyperCard, SuperCard, and Visual Basic.  If you remember HyperCard, you will recognize the concept of a page, a background, and a stack.

DBJr lets you store information freeform without the restrictions of a database.  You customize the action of a button by writing a script.  It is even possible to make games and other mini-applications.

DBJr is an application inside of the Lively Kernel programming environment.  Any graphical object in

126.storedString:
can be placed on a page.  

                                            Click the Next button  -->

163.comment: Read this stack to find out about stacks!  (It is a stack itself.)

173.textString:
DBJr is an end-user authoring system in the tradition of HyperCard, SuperCard, and Visual Basic.  If you remember HyperCard, you will recognize the concept of a page, a background, and a stack.

DBJr lets you store information freeform without the restrictions of a database.  You customize the action of a button by writing a script.  It is even possible to make games and other mini-applications.

DBJr is an application inside of the Lively Kernel programming environment.  Any graphical object in Lively Kernel can be placed on a page.  

                                            Click the Next button  -->

185.textString:
This introduction is itself a DBJr stack.  You are looking at a page.  The Previous ( < ) and Next ( > ) buttons below turn to another page.  Pages that look the same belong to the same background.  

If you move a field or a button on a background, the change will be seen on all pages of that background.  

A stack is an arrangement of pages in order.  Pages of different backgrounds can be intermixed in a stack.

The next page in this stack has a different visual style because it belongs to a different background.

306.storedString:
No, this is not a diagram of the layers in DBJr.  DBJr allows you to use any kind of morphic object.  A picture such as a sketch or a jpeg is just like any other object.  You can put as many as you want on a page or a background.   

In DBJr, all background objects are behind all page-specific objects.

315.textString:
DBJr is similar to Apple's HyperCard (1987, by Bill Atkinson and team).  

HyperCard was in black-and-white, and the only objects allowed were buttons, text fields, and pictures.

321.textString:
No, this is not a diagram of the layers in DBJr.  DBJr allows you to use any kind of morphic object.  A picture such as a sketch or a jpeg is just like any other object.  You can put as many as you want on a page or a background.   

In DBJr, all background objects are behind all page-specific objects.

561.textString:
On the right is a Contacts stack.  Turn its pages.  Each page can have custom objects on it. 

The text is not in database fields, but is just text.  People are different, and you want to remember different things about them.  Searching for an essential word may be easier than trying to look up a person by his or her name.

If you want to make separate fields for name and address, you may do so.

Contacts is a stack within a stack.  Stacks and other objects can be embedded inside each other as deeply as needed.

568.textString:
Any morph can be on a page.  Please drag some new objects into this page.

When a morph is dropped, it goes on just one page.  It has the property 'pageSpecific'.  

When a morph is on a page, its menu has the item
'be in background'.

A background morph has 
'be on this page only'.

A text field in the background can be the same on every page, or it can have per-page text (like this text field).  Choose 'be per page text'.

Also, see the menu by clicking ( <> ) in the stack controls.

573.textString:
This world has a prototype stack and page (the blue and gray rectangles at the lower right).  

To make a new stack, execute:

$world.get("Stack").demo()

The new stack will be at the top left of the world.  Drag it by its gray header.

The stack you are reading was built in the user interface from the demo stack.

578.textString:
Expand the ObjectEditor below to see the code for DBJr.  There are just 14 methods.

In addition, there is class PageData, and modifications to Morph.addMorph (to make it page-specific) and Morph.morphMenuItems (to add the menu items).
